captions.text:
I'm going to show you the sound of a
clap ...

and I don't mean some digital depiction
of a clap. I mean that when this man's

hands come together you're going to see
something that is normally invisible.

You're going to see the actual
sound wave leaving his hands and
traveling outward at 761 miles per hour --
the speed of sound!
And here it is again.
How is this possible?

Well, I'll start the explanation not with
sound but with the heat

from a lighter. There's a puff of butane,
sparks fly,

and the fuel ignites. But that shape
billowing up from the flame isn't smoke --
That's normal air that has been expanded by heat.
We're able to see the density change thanks to a technique called

Schlieren Flow Visualization.
Here's how it works.
You start off with a light, shining through a single slit.

If you reflect that light of a parabolic
mirror all the rays become parallel

and then you can use another parabolic
mirror to refocus the light down to a single focal point

and then in through the lens of a camera
to make a picture.

Now here's the trick -- you place some 
sort of barrier right at the focal point.

Now you add something that will distort
the air -- like a candle.

The candle will block light rays making a
silhouette, and the flame will make light.

But rising heat will change the density of
the air above the lighter

and that will bend the light rays. The
bent light ray won't pass through the focal point.

it will be blocked by the barrier ... and
the picture will be darker.

This technique can be used to see
anything that distorts the air.

The heat from a hair straightener for
example.
Even the heat coming off a human hand.

Epidemiologists used to study 
sneezes and coughs.

Engineers use it to study 
aerodynamic flow.

And sound? Well -- that's just another
change in air density.
A traveling compression wave. So Schlieren Visualization

along with a high speed camera can be
used to see it as well.
Here's a book landing on a table.
The end of a towel being snapped.
A firecracker.
An AK-47.
And of course, a clap.

comments.author: the747videoer

comments.text:
Sort of. 

Humidity and temperature affects how intense sound can be because of the 
way it affects density in air. 

If its true that denser air diminishes how intense sound is, we can see how 
temperature and humidity can affect density in air.

Instead of thinking of it like amplification, however, think of it as 
resistance/damping. I.e., certain levels of temperature and humidity dampen 
sound less due to how dense the air is as a result of temp and humidity vs 
other levels of temp and humidity. 

Say colder more humid air is very dense air. Sound will need to work harder 
to maintain a certain level of intensity. Compare that to dryer, more warm 
air. Sound in that scenario won't have to work as hard to maintain a 
certain level of intensity. 

Hopefully this made sense and if I'm incorrect on anything id love to hear 
a correction.

comments.author: Mahendar Kumbham

comments.text:
In the mid-19th century, German physicist August Toepler invented a 
photography technique called Schlieren Flow Visualization that allows to 
see things that are normally invisible. It can also be used to see sound.

Read the article here: 
http://www.npr.org/2014/04/09/300563606/what-does-sound-look-like   
#visualization   #science  ﻿

comments.text:
i still dont get how sound always travels with the same speed, when exposed 
to the same circumstances. when you clap, your hands certainly don't move 
at the speed of sound, but the sound coming from the clap, is. all the 
things that generate sound, including me typing right now, have different 
speeds, yet the sound coming from everything remains at constant speed of 
around 330 m/s. (in the same circumstances) i also wondered what a 
supersonic explosion, or in other words, a detonation would be like, since 
it produces a schockwave faster than the speed of sound. i don't realy know 
for sure whether this supersonic schockwave, is supersonic going through 
the explosive material, and slowing down to the speed of sound when it 
exits. but i assume it remains faster than the speed of sound for a while. 
even outside of the explosive material. so if you were to be standing at a 
distance of about 300 meters from a detonation. would you first feel the 
schockwave, and then hear the sound, or would the sound be carried with the 
schockwave. maybe when you are standing 3000 meters away from a detonation 
you could feel and hear the difference, a bit better. i'm realy curious how 
this works, can anyone explain this to me?     .     
please excuse my english, it is not my native language.﻿

comments.author: Bastiaan Hoornweg

comments.text:
There's a lot of complicated physics and math involved, but think of it 
like this -- if you have a long row of dominoes lined up, and knock over 
the first one, it doesn't much matter how fast or slow you knock over the 
first one -- once things get going, the speed at which the line of dominoes 
go down depends on the properties of the dominoes (how tall they are, how 
heavy, how far apart, etc.) not the speed or force with which you knocked 
over the first one.  Even if you kicked the first one very hard and it 
slammed into the first two dozen dominoes at high speed instead of just 
gently hitting domino #2, eventually the initial force will stop mattering 
and the rest of the dominoes will be falling at the usual speed typical of 
those kinds of dominoes.  The case of sound in air is a bit more 
complicated, but the same idea holds -- the mass and density and elastic 
properties of the air molecules will ultimately determine the speed that 
the sound disturbance propagates through the air, regardless of the speed 
or force of the initial sound-making movement.  The force of the 
sound-maker will determine how MUCH the air moves (like the height of an 
ocean wave can vary), but won't have any effect on how *fast* the 
disturbance from the noise gets from one place to another.  The "ripple" 
through air happens at the same speed, just like the falling dominoes fall 
at a constant speed.

comments.author: Tom Martin

comments.text:
+Tom Martin You could blow smoke rings, but you would not be able to see 
them. This technique shows everything that bends light, including air.

Basically, the reason you can see smoke rings normally is because the smoke 
is visible, and the air is not. In this case, wether you're using smoke and 
air, or air and air, you will see both substances. When a smoke ring moves 
through air, it displaces air while it travels, and the air it displaces, 
also displaces air. Normally you wouldn't see it, but you can with this 
technique.

Instead of a nice clean ring, you'd see a large clump of air swirling 
around in random directions, following the rings direction. But you 
wouldn't see the ring, because the displacing air around it would mask it.
